Guacamole - this was such a fail. Very bland, needed salt, garlic, and onion. 

Ceviche Mixto - this was also bland, where is the citrus?

Brussel sprouts - this was decent and fine on flavor

After 3 out of 4 failed dishes, we left without trying entrees since we wanted to cut our losses early, and instead went to another restaurant down the street.

I will give 1 star for the adorable twinkle lights in the ceiling, and 1 star for being helpful getting us drinks quickly.

Would not return however as the food just isnt good.
author: Mary X.

description: Guac and chips are good, but other items were not great. Salad was WAY overdressed and oversalted. Veggie tacos were solid, but the quesadilla left something to be desired.
author: J. A.

description: Best Mexican food in the WORLD !!!!!!!!!!! The service is superb, people are very friendly, and food is delicious!  Every time we come here we enjoyed our experiences very much. Highly recommend this place for a relaxing atmosphere and great food!
author: Angela L.

description:
I am a taco snob. I could eat tacos for the rest of my life. Tacos are my favorite food group. So here is my taco tragedy. Take pity upon me.

My friend brought me here for dinner, after he found it on yelp, and I ordered the carnitas street tacos ($10 - for two street tacos? really?!). When I tried the carnitas, it was fatty and unseasoned. So I put the habanero hot sauce (offered to me by our server) on top, in heaps, hoping to add some flavor, but their habanero hot sauce lacked flavor *and* heat (how? What witch craft is this?!) 

And that is the story of how I only ate one street taco and let the waitress throw the other in the trash (after declining her numerous offers to give me a box). 

Anyway, if you like the taste of soggy paper, this is probably the spot for you!
author: Tiffany S.

description: Had the carne tacos, absolutely delicious. For me, the seating is too close together, chairs are uncomfortable and service was a little slow- otherwise it would have been 5 stars. Love the mural. Great lunch spot in Hayes Valley on a weekend when most are serving brunch only.
author: D M.

description: Really good Mexican food in Hayes Valley. My boyfriend & I were walking around & decided to eat here after a long day of shopping. We were seated quickly & were able to order within a few minutes. The atmosphere was lively & every single table was taken. The wait staff were very attentive & brought out our drinks & appetizers promptly. The guacamole is really good. It came with a blend of tomato, red onion & cucumber. We shared the fajitas which came with Spanish rice, black beans & tortillas. We split steak & shrimp. The fajitas were flavorful however the only drawback was just a bit too much oil. Next time I come, I'll just ask for easy oil. All in all great place for good Mexican food.
author: Nancy F.

description: Met a couple of friends here while we were in town. Service was super friendly, food came fast and was delicious. Prices were reasonable and portion size was great. The blood orange margarita was awesome. Great little spot!
author: Taylor J.

description:
THE BEST MEXICAN FOOD.
David fajitas are the best,salsa verde,for sure the Sangria. All the Desserts is something that I can eat everyday (specially Flan). 
If you are looking a for nice, clean, friendly place come to  PAPITOS. 
I love the SANGRIA
author: Danny H.

description: Fantastic value. I've had several dishes here and their beef pineapple tacos are easily their best item, very juicy and tender.
author: Brian P.

description:
Our small group of three was happy to find a restaurant open on New Year's Day after watching a show at the War Memorial Opera House. Had a great feel about the place...loved the vibe and the twinkling lights as well as the beautiful painting on the wall. Service was good and everyone was helpful and jovial. As my sister lived in Mexico City for 7 years and as we were born and raised in a border town in Arizona, we are not strangers to outrageously delicious Mexican food.  Sadly, we did not find it here. 

We liked the Esquites appetizer...very bright flavors...the tomatoes were incredible. The special soup was Caldo de Cameron and it was tasty...the soup had a great flavor and there were tons of veggies and shrimp. It had an aftertaste, however, that I couldn't put my finger on but reminded me of something musty. 

My sister had the carnitas quesadilla.  The carnitas was yummy she reported, however, instead of tidy packages of crunchy, manageable meat, cheese and tortilla, her quesadilla was mushy, messy and overstuffed. 

I had the fish tacos which were reported to be made of Rockfish (which I not only was raised on from my family's fishing forays to the Sea of Cortez, but also eat frequently since I live in near Bodega Bay and it is so prevalent here) but the fish in the tacos tasted like tilapia...a flavor and texture I do not like as I think tilapia tastes like Catfish....muddy and mushy).  The fish was fried crispy and the seasoning was good. The cabbage slaw was tasty as was the sauce.  My sister and I had a side of beans, which were black beans, and they were simple and tasty. 

Our friend ordered the grilled chicken and it not only looked delicious but she reported it was delicious...tender and tasty and she ate every bite. The plantains that came along side, which she shared, were Caramelized perfectly and were super yummy. 

Two stars because how do you mess up a quesadilla?? And be true to your ingredients....maybe I'm wrong about the fish but I think I'm right.
author: Tanya K.

description:
The place is intimate as far as size goes, there's only a handful of tables and booths. We walked in right after the lunch rush and luckily they were able to accommodate us fairly quickly with no wait at all. 

We hunkered down in our booth with the menus and our eyes glazed over with all the choices. We decided on the corn 'Esquites' appetizer to start and a pitcher of regular margaritas ($30, ~5). The margaritas were deceptively strong and between two people we got roughly 2.5 each. 

I was kind of craving a handful of their items, but ultimately decided to split an appetizer and a wet burrito with my boyfriend (it was the right choice as the burrito was massive). We shared the Albondigas which were good but only came with two meatballs and the rest was all brussel sprouts (not a bad thing, but when you order meatballs you kind of expect more of those than the veg they're served with). We ordered the 'Burrito Mojada' with both sauces (a good choice, I recommend doing this) no meat because we knew it was going to be large. While it wasn't the most amazing burrito I have ever eaten, I was all about those sauces which were both memorable and full of flavor.
author: Siobhan F.

description:
Good food and good service.  Today was my first visit and it was a success. I'll return.  The Shrimp Quasidilla was nice.  It had a mango and apple salsa that was on the sweet side for my taste but it was still delicious.  My friend ordered the pork burrito and he loved it.  We were craving French fries when we arrived so we ordered the French Fries with Aioli side dish as an appetizer.  The Fries were hot and delicious.  Hit the spot.  We also ordered a bottle of the Brute Rose sparkling wine and it went nicely with the dishes that we ordered.

Nice place with friendly staff.
author: Donna P.

description:
Lovely mexican restaurant. Good fresh ceviche and tacos. 
orange margarita and spicy Bloody Mary are tasty. 
Home made guacamole is awesome and so was the shrimp salad. However the mole con pollo quesadilla is a little on the bitter side. 
The place is little get pretty crowded but it is good for a quick lunch.
author: Marina S.

description: Came here pre-concert at the Civic (6 min walk), and was able to get seated immediately at 6PM, whereas most other usual "pre-Symphony" eateries were all res'd up. Actually was very, very good, with the guac to start, mix and match taco selection a winner, along with the blood orange Margaritas (this was a Jimmy Buffett concert after all), finished off with flan.
author: RJ D.

description:
There's definitely a "win some, lose some" situation with this spot.

You definitely win in terms of location. It's located at the heart of Hayes Valley which provides a very fun nightlife scene. There is a great selection of bars you can go to after dinner, and that's a nice perk. It's a perfect place for date night.

Unless you took a bus, you definitely lose when it comes to finding parking. I'm sure you aren't a fan of taking circles around the same block over and over, right? I'm not either. You also lose out on moolah. It is by no means meant to be a cheap spot to dine at. Be prepared to spend about $25 a person just for the entree alone.

Now, if what you've read so far is totally fine with you, then I welcome you to the world of Papito! It's a cozy spot that has awesome wall decorations (see picture) and is generally very compact (it can be very busy on weekends since there isn't a bunch of room). Though I've only been here two times, both were very enjoyable. They serve unique enchiladas here, and they are by far my favorite dish. What is it that makes them unique? They are served in a bowl in tortillas that are usually meant for fajitas. Underneath them is the beans and rice (see picture). I don't think that's anything revolutionary, but it's different.

Final verdict: Papito is a small little place that offers an intimate setting. The cooks here know what they are doing and in turn you get great food. Service, as per usual with any place, can be slow if you happen to be there on a busy night. Regardless, it is most definitely worth a try.
author: Alex B.

description: Yummy food, excellent atmosphere and service. Go in the evening when it's all lit up. We had homemade chips with guacamole, brussel sprouts (don't miss this one!), Grilled salmon, flan (you just don't want to miss their flan!) and churros. Everything was delicious! The service was good too! I'm so glad.
author: Rex T.

description: Great food, solid margaritas, attentive staff! Coming out here for the first time and will come again.
author: Sandra G.

description: One of our go to spots in the neighborhood! Solid food and drinks. The place is tiny so expect a wait on Fridays and Saturdays. The tables are also really close to each other you can hear your neighbors entire conversation. We've tried a few different items but really like the veggie enchiladas and fried chicken quesadilla.
author: Monika V.

description: Really Great Margaritas and really enjoyed the vibe the food wasn't anything super special but really enjoyed it. Had my first oyster shooter which was surprisingly tasty and kind of spicy!
author: Kelsey C.

description:
I was in the area for the Google Mini Donut shop, so my boyfriend and I decided to give Papito a try. I ordered the vegetable enchiladas, my boyfriend a torta, and we also ordered nachos as an appetizer.
The "nachos" turned out to be OK, except if I wanted chips and Guac I would've ordered that instead.
My enchiladas were perfectly ruined by some sweet cinnamon sauce that was drizzled on top. I saw some green salsa in there, but the cinnamon dominated in flavor. 
My boyfriend did not complain, but he wasn't impressed. 

Service was average.
author: Monica V.

description:
I eat tacos every.damn.day so it's rare that I'll go somewhere and pay $4 for a fairly small taco, but for realzies, these tacos are worth it and then some. Or at least the two types of tacos and burrito I tried were.

I didn't get the blood orange margarita but one of my friends did and it was the star beverage for sure. It was the least sweet margarita I've ever had and was dangerously drinkable. I got a quality beer that was budget-friendly at $4 (despite its high caliber craft status). 

Service was spectacular and I like that the place offers really comfortable seating with plenty of space for your table mates (despite not being very large overall).  

My dining partners and I split the chips, salsa, and guacamole and while all good, the entrees are where Papito West stole the show. 

That sauteed shrimp burrito +  Vegetariano tacos (roasted corn, cauliflower, pasilla peppers, wild mushrooms, orange oaxaca sauce & cheese) + camaron costeno taco: sauteed shrimp, garlic, chile de arbol sauce, avocado, cilantro, red onions &a apple mango pico de gallo, are going to be hard to beat. Like, I'd suit up right now and go back for a bite right now if I thought they'd still be open.
author: Candice G.

description: Meeeeeh. We've all had better. It's average Mexican food and nothing to drool over. My waitress convinced me to get the chicken fajitas ("a classic!!!") and it was heavy and covered in sauce. Mostly ate the rice. And if you sit outside like we did, you'll appreciate the heat lamps but likely be neglected by wait-staff. So, you know.
author: Katie K.

description: The thought of waiting in line to eat a burrito is completely insane to me, but not if it is for the fried chicken burrito at Papito's. Fried chicken=yum, burrito =good, and fried chicken burrito=ahhhh-mazing.  The duck confit burrito is also good, but I really walk all the way from Pacific heights for the fried chicken burrito. The burrito paired with the Watermelon Agua Fresca is the perfect meal....even if you have to pay for it later ().
author: Julie B.

description: I had a stressful business meeting with my client, even though it's a Sunday we had a few drinks, nothing major a few glasses of wine, I was nervous and felt dizzy. I am in sales. I walked into Papito approximately 3 p.m. I am and was met by a short Latin (I assume ) waiter. He disrespected me and asked me to leave. If he felt something was off he could have offered me a water. Instead I was basically "kicked out" and denied service. I am disappointed in this type of customer service and disrespect. As an attorney, I have never been disrespected more. I am disturbed the way I was treated and the embarrassment I have endured. Please contact me with any questions but this is a true disappointment.
author: Lena D.

description:
This place is the best I have been to in the Hayes, yet, for the price range. The inside is tiny but they also have a couple cute tables outside. It's really built for tables of two but they can accommodate more, you may just have to wait awhile.

We shared the tuna tartare with the chipotle emulsion. So good! I could have had one all to myself! The trio of salsa is ok, I'd rather go for the guacamole next time. We didn't even finish half of the salsas.

For mains we tried the carne asada and the grilled chicken. The portions are decent and the steak was cooked brilliantly! More medium than medium rare but I think the cook was struggling with getting temps right, the table next to us sent back both of their steaks for being rare. It was still seasoned nicely and tasted so good. We subbed out the fried and sweet potato mash for vegetables. The brussel sprouts and veggies. Both were good. Be aware though that the sprouts came with cheese but it wasn't on the menu. I can't have cheese but I was able to eat around it. The portion for the chicken was huge! A breast and a thigh, I think. Cooked with the skin on. It lacked flavor and the tomatillo salsa didn't complement it enough.

We'll be back and probably try the tacos and guacamole. Get there early because it's small, they don't seem to take reservations, and it's popular!
author: Jess A.

description: Highly recommend the Baja tacos above all else. The charred habanero margs are great, but stick to a couple instead of a pitcher. Pass on the queso if you're going for melty / cheesy. It's more similar to a bean dip. Fun atmosphere.
author: Abigail S.

description:
More of a 3.5* but I go too often to round down :)

Not your Mission taqueria but some solid stuff:

Super burrito (I get it with chorizo) is BIG and the guac in it is very good. Better burritos in the city for sure but not bad at all.

Shrimp enchiladas are great but they skimp a bit on the shrimp quantity. Otherwise very tasty.

Decent margaritas and GREAT habanero salsa which has good flavor and a nice kick.

Papitos is somewhat lucky to have a little monopoly on Hayes st as the only Mexican place there but as a Hayes resident, it does the job
author: Farid V.

description:
Papito is a cozy, hip restaurant in the heart of Hayes Valley that serves "california fresh" Mexican food. This isn't the kind of Mexican food you find in Mission joints like El Farolito (although there is always an occasion for El Farolito fare, like drunk at 2am). Papito Hayes serves an elevated take on Mexican classics and I was surely not disappointed. 

My two roommates and I went on a Friday night around 7pm and was seated within a couple minutes without a reservation (they don't take reservations). We were prepared to wait 30 min just because the restaurant is pretty small, so we were off to great start! 

APPETIZERS: 
+Guacamole & Chips $9: Guacamole was chunky and tasty! Great starter dish, but it wasn't anything out of this world. I prefer the guacamole at Mamacita more. The waitress was attentive and refilled our chips whenever we ran low, so +1 for the awesome service!

+Esquites $9: We ordered this not really knowing what it was, but basically it's a grilled corn salsa. It was a light side dish that paired well with our chips. But for $9, I would've rather just had another order of guacamole. Don't order, you can make it at home. 

ENTREES:
+Duck Confit taco: the duck was shredded, full of flavor, generously portioned, and juicy. The pickled topping & mint tamarind sauce brought a breath of freshness that cut the saltiness & fattiness of the duck. So fantastic. Would definitely order this one again. 

+Fish taco: fried rock cod with a cabbage slaw on top. It was good, but not anything that isn't served elsewhere for cheaper. Wouldn't order this one unless you've never had a fish taco in your life, haha.

+Carne Asada Quesadilla: the shining star of the night. The quesadilla was conveniently served as 3 thick triangular slices, one for each of us. The caramelized peppers and onions are perfect with the skirt steak, which was not dry at all and packed with flavor. I really enjoyed the fresh radish they put in the quesadilla because it made the otherwise really heavy dish feel lighter. ORDER THIS ONE! 

DRINKS: 
+Blood Orange Margarita: Very drinkable! Not too strong, not too weak. But it was VERY tangy. I didn't mind it too much, but my roommate was adding water to hers to dilute it because it was too sour for her. Maybe next time I'll ask for some sugar to offset the sourness? But I would still order it again because its pink, pretty, and got me tipsy :P
author: Erica L.

description: This is a great spot for a nice casual dinner - but beware if you have allergies. They label the menu with allergies but be sure to tell the server because the denotations are not accurate! The carnitas are marked gluten free but they have beer in them. Beware if you have celiac!
author: Katrina G.

description: This is my neighborhood taco spot! These are not random 2$taco Tuesday tacos but the kind my grandmother use to make with marinated meats, fish and poultry paired with chile, crema and avocado, small bites packed with crunch and flavor! The shrimp are a personal favorite and I still can't eat more than two.
author: Dolores J.

description:
Great spot in Hayes Valley. 

I recommend the oysters, tuna enchipotlado, and the tacos. 

Just get a selection of plates and a beer. You can't go wrong.
author: Felix C.

description:
Delicious vegetarian options with a warm intimate feel are all I need for a dinner date. The wait time for dinner Friday night for a party of 6 was about one hour. This location does not have too much space but the decor is very artistic! I highly recommend for a dinner date or girls night. The guacamole was delicious but I wasn't a huge fan of their chips. We had blood orange margaritas with dinner and they were so flavorful and really cut the tang of the tequila. For dinner, we chose veggie quesadillas and veggie enchiladas, both of which were great. The standout ingredients were their fresh corn and mushrooms, in fact, the vegetables were
cooked very well.
author: Shruti S.

description: The duck here is great and a stand out. Their spicy margaritas and sangria is great too
author: Monique S.

description:
Service is great and quick . Small place , can fit about 30 people at any time. 

We ordered the Red sangria and trust me , this is a potent drink. I feel like they pur a bit of brandy in there as well. We got the guacamole for starters. Pretty perfect and served in a Stone bowl, a generous amount i must add. 

We had the vegetarian enchilladas stuffed with peppers and mushroom served with black beans and rice. Good portion size so two people could share . With a little of their habenero sauce, the taste was spot on . They even use their own home made cheese me thinks . It had the texture of crumbled feta cheese. 

We finished with the flan served with strawberries and mexican wedding cookie . Everything about this meal was just right.
author: Vasini G.

description: Came here for dinner with the bf on a Saturday night after a quick shopping trip, and it was just what we were looking for! It's in a really fun area, so even though there was a 30 minute wait after we put our names on the list, we were able to occupy ourselves by checking out some of the nearby shops. We were seated outside, and even though it was a little chilly, the heat lamps they have are pretty good. We started with the chips and salsa trio. The tomato-based one was kind of smokey which I liked, the tomatillo one had a good bite to it, and the mango one was different. I liked the first 2, but the mango seemed more like a mango purée than a salsa to me. The chips were warm fresh and crispy, and they are unlimited, making them a really great deal for only $3! For entrees, I got the mole chicken enchiladas and my boyfriend got the carne asada enchiladas. They were more like tacos that were warmed up with some extra toppings, but they were pretty tasty! And while the portions looked small at first, we were actually satisfied with those portions. Only reasons we wouldn't give this place 5 stars was the enchiladas were probable a few dollars more expensive than they're worth, and we felt like they were trying to get us out of the restaurant more quickly near he end of our meal. Overall, we'd probably come back if we're in the area and craving some Mexican!
author: Rachel D.

description:
Two Sisters was closed for a private event. I was out last night late for Dia de los Muertos and every single taqueria was a zoo, including La Taqueria. I was therefore deprived of Mexican food. Strangely, today's catered lunch at work was fajitas, but seeing that that was aimed to white fin tech valley people, it was blend. I wanted something more than that tonight. 

I could swear that I'd eaten at Papito in Potrero because the restaurant sounded familiar, so I showed up here already knowing what to order. Soup. Or pozole rojo. Dumped all the chili and chopped onions into the bowl, and squeezed the lime's last drop of juice. Soup was incredibly spicy, perfect for a cold evening. Crudo was amazing, actually, with black sesame seeds, jicama and avocado mouse. Interesting presentation. Strawberry with blood orange margarita was too blood orangy but if you like that citrus, you are all set. Asada enchiladas for my companion who clearly was not wiling to share. Whatever. 

Season ticket holder to City Arts and Lectures at the Nourse means that I have become very good friends with restaurants in Hayes Valley. Have become slightly bored of Rich Table, Chez Maman, Plaj, Suppenkuche, Lers Ros, Mazzat, Jardiniere, Monsieur Bejamin, Grove, Absinthe, Sauce, or Souvla, my choices have become rather slim. 

When evaluating restaurants that are highly regarded by most people in the city who would like to dine out in Hayes Valley, think the following:

1. Is it cold outside?
2. Did you not able to get into another Mexican restaurant?
3. Do you like good quality organic Mexican food?
4. Can you get a table and be done eating in 40 minutes?
5. Not willing to fork over $100+ on a meal in Hayes Valley tonight?

If yes, come here. 

I sure will.
author: Victoria E.

description: A great little taqueria in the middle of the Hayes Valley commercial district. Always looks busy but turn over is quick and we were seated in about five minutes. Really enjoyed the chicken Milanese torta and fries and veggie quesadilla. High quality ingredients presented in a unique way. Only complaint was the chips were somewhat stale. I asked about this and they said they were made fresh that day, but my guess is that they dry up since they keep them exposed to the open air. Otherwise, very good.
author: Chris D.

description: A bit pricey for average tasting food, I got 2 tacos for $10 and a pre made $10 Margherita which wasn't worth the price. The guacamole is okay...
author: Jules G.

description: The food and drinks were great.  It's really, really loud in there though.  I found it kind of difficult to have a conversation just across the table.
author: Norman M.

description:
I'm here NOW and EVERY weekend. I love the place, I love the food & I LOVE the service. David, Raul and William know how to make customers regulars. 

I get by during the week by dreaming about their menu and reward myself by coming here Saturday or Sunday mornings (sometimes both). 

Chips, guacamole and pico de gallo, duhh. 
Papito salad with chicken, yes. 
And everything else, pleaseee! xx
author: Vicky M.

description:
Delicious!!  We came to Papito on a recommendation and boy are we glad we tried it.
Taking Mexican food to another level.  Their chips and salsa trio are great, and the food was made with love.  I had a Carnitas Quesadilla.. melt in your mouth carnitas with grilled pineapple and pick de gallo... amazing.  My Fiancé had the chicken mole enchiladas which were like your grandma made then.  The wait staff are super-friendly and caring, and make the whole dining experience a pleasure.  We are instant fans of this great Hayes Valley treasure, and will definitely be back!!
author: Christine Z.

description:
Poor man's nopalito...except mediocre food that's a few dollars too pricey. Service was fine. Got busy around 630 on a Wednesday night. 

Had the chips/salsa, ceviche mixto, shrimp enchiladas. Salsa didn't have any heat. Ceviche needed to be chopped a bit more--nobody wants to eat a straight up octopus leg.
author: Semuteh F.

description: We've been here a few times after visiting the theatre and each time has been top notch.  Good creativity woven into typical Mexican fare.  Drinks were also very good.  We brought our kids but could be a fun date spot too.  Best Mexican we've had since moving to the Bay!
author: Mike C.

description: Papito Hayes is a great place to have lunch.  The customer service is fabulous and great quality of tasty food, you won't be disappointed!  It's authentic and delicious.  Papito Hayes ambiance is relaxed and fun for work or for family and friends.  Check it out... it's worth your time and your taste buds will be happy.
author: Lynnette W.

description:
I was walking towards Octavia to see the "Before I Die" wall when I noticed Papito.  My coworker and I decided to check it out and we ended up getting our lunches to go.  I got 4 tacos for $15: 2 chicken tacos and 2 shrimp tacos.  The shrimp tacos were decent.  I wish there was more shrimp.  But it was nonetheless good.  I really liked the chicken ones.  The tacos were fully loaded with chicken and I was completely stuffed when I finished my lunch.

The restaurant is small and intimate.  I'd like to come back for brunch.
author: Vira P.

description:
Overall, very unremarkable Mexican food. The guacamole was pretty good, but very salty. The "super burrito" wasn't bad, but wasn't particularly good, either. It came with a side of salsa that was neither spicy nor tasty. My other complaint is that they don't have pinto beans, only black beans. 

I wouldn't come back here when there are so many better options for the same pricr, like Tacobar on California or my personal favorite, Green Chile Kitchen on McAllister.
author: Lauren C.

description:
My bestie and I like to try new places, especially ones raved to be the best by other friends. The duck burrito was highly recommended so we were on a mission to try it!

We had:

Equites- it sounded like the typical Mexican corn with the cheese and other goodies on the outside. What we got was a warm dish of already shucked corn. Score! Easy to eat, but a little heavy on the salt. It may have been the cheese. I wouldn't order this again. 

Super burrito- We had it with duck confit. The ingredients are fresh and you can taste it. I didn't think the duck went well with the burrito. I ordered the enchilada with duck to go for M and it was way better. The duck is on the sweet side, so paired better with the spicy red enchilada sauce. 

Papito Tacos- tempura shrimp was very good! Plump, juicy, nice crisp breading. I didn't care for the cabbage. I'd order again with less cabbage or just none at all.

Overall, it was just an okay experience. Food was just mehh. Not bad, but nothing too exciting. Service was good though. Everyone was very nice.
author: Lena H.

description:
A Mexican place in Hayes Valley??? Get outta here! Yep, that's right folks. Papito is cooking up some good mood food for sure. 
The music is chill and the vibe is low-key. Whether you're looking for a down and dirty burrito or a sit-down "big plate" you've come to the right place. Service is on par and the food speaks for itself. You won't find a mariachi band here but you're sure to leave with a smile, and full stomach. Cheers Papito West. You've done it again.
author: Kevin J.

description: Was expecting a lot after a great recommendation. We were pretty disappointed in the quality. The portions were large.. not worth the price. Didn't even get the chips and salsa we ordered.
author: LeAnn F.

description: My boyfriend and I live around the corner and we're so happy to live so close. We love this place! The food is amazing. He always gets the skirt steak burrito, and I rotate through the 4 taco options. The burrito is a great size and the tacos have been satisfying every time. The servers here are also incredibly friendly and welcoming! We've sat outside each time so I can't speak about the interior. The outdoor heaters work SO well, it's no trouble sitting outside even when it's chilly out! (We always come with our dog.) Also a huge fan of their drinks. Highly recommend!
author: Jessica F.

description: Best al pastor I've ever had. Had it on the quesadilla and it was fantastic. Perfect flavor, the meat was tender and juicy, and the perfect amount of pineapple! Couldn't be happier with how the meal went. Also, our waiter was very attentive. He gave us extra chips the second we ran out of our first round.
author: Jamison M.

description: Crappy food not worthy of being called Mexican food. The food is bland and has small portions for the price. Should've listened to friends that live here that said everyone that eats here doesn't recommend. Not worth the time
author: Daisy G.

description:
Organic Mexican food? Yeah, might sound odd, but it was d'lish!

We had a quesadilla, ceviche mixto, and the brussel sprouts. The brussels were off the hook!! Absolutely recommend these.
The ceviche was amazing, too, but the chips it came with were crap :). (Seemed store bought.) I think I ate the ceviche by itself, and it tasted fresh and amazing.
My hubby wasn't thrilled with his quesadilla, he thought it lacked a bit of flavor, but was better with added salt and salsa. He wished there was a spicier salsa to add a better kick. 
We will be back. 4 stars for food, 5 stars for service and the fact that you're getting organic!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Read the good reviews and saw it was packed so the wife and I figured it would be a good place to sit back and eat. Despite how busy it was we were seated in about 10 minutes. The waiter came to us pretty quick to get drink orders. He pushed the sangria and stated it was ver good. He was very wrong. Do not order sangria here, it's well below par. 

The food however was the opposite of the sangria. We had the veggie cheese dip appetizer, vegetarian enchiladas and ceviche mixto(seafood one). All of it was amazing. I was full about 3/4 of way into meal but could not stop. I didn't try the dessert but if it's anything like the main courses and appetizers then it will be grand. 

I do recommend this place to eat for the service, food, and atmosphere. Just avoid the sangria.
author: James A.

description:
Decent tacos, but I'd still take a taqueria's tacos in the Mission any day.

Any place that makes me pay for salsa is bad news bears in my book.

Wouldn't go back. Whattashame.
author: Gabriela W.

description: Very bland food. Service is great but unfortunately for them the food is just doesn't have enough flavor. Seems like a hot spot due to trendy location and interior
author: Sarah G.

description: Today i was craving a burrito. So someone recommend this place to me. I was looking at the menu & seen that a regular burrito was 9 or 10 dollars which sounds about right. So i ordered that to find out i still had to pay an additional 5 dollars for meat.?? So basically i payed 10 dollars for a tortilla with rice and beans. And 5 dollars for meat. ?  Wow... When i started eating it was mostly beans and rice barely any meat & barely any flavor. Never ordering here again. Thanks anyways.
author: Adriana M.

description: Cerviche was great and a huge portion with chips that can be shared between 2-3 people. We got 4 different types of tacos and I think they were all great mixes of ingredients and meats. The pulled pork was great!! I think you only need 2-3 per person and the prices were very reasonable. I would definitely come back again and try some of their other food!
author: Lily P.

description: Food is very good but horrible customer service. Takes too long to get anything and I was forced to leave extra tips even though it was not deserved.
author: Helen S.

description:
Stopped by here on a weekday afternoon to grab a quick lunch. Everything = SO GOOD.

I got the Papito Salad and added carnitas. By doing that I saved $3 in extra lettuce and the meat/veggie ratio was spot on. Lots of meat, not mostly salad. The dressing was light and citrusy. My boyfriend got the pozole and they brought this cute little side place with extra fixin's to season to your liking. The broth was delicious and it came out piping hot. 

I'd definitely be back! Others' meals around us looked delicious too.
author: Carol M.

description:
Upscale Mexican food located right in the heart of Hayes Valley.

Intimate setting, with a relaxed atmosphere and great service.

I had the shrimp enchiladas which were very good in served a unique style which I didn't expect.

As with most things in Hayes Valley, this place is slightly overpriced. But overall a great place to grab some margaritas and some quality food.
author: Eric B.

description: Awesome place. Cool decor and food was super tasty. Shrimp salad was great. Carnitas quesadilla was awesome too.
author: Lori S.

description: The headline here is "should have walked the 18 minutes to Nopalito". Let's talk about margaritas. Remember back when a margarita was cheap tequila disguised with triple sec, lime and sour mix? Yeah, well that's the only option here-- no decent tequila, no Cointreau, No Gran Marnier, just dreck. It's hard to believe a place in Hayes Valley would get away with this. If people are OK with that fine but at least offer an "upgrade"! We ordered shrimp ceviche and a mushroom quesadilla. The ceviche was sweet in a bad way (the roasted pineapple I guess) and warm room temperature. Not cool. I sent it back, bartender was very accommodating and didn't charge me for it. The quesadilla was great but then again a five year old can make quesadillas. When there are oh so many great places to eat here, why choose this one?
author: Luke A.

description:
Some friends and I came here on a Tuesday night for dinner. There was actually a small line outside, but we got really lucky with our party of three and got seated immediately. Atmosphere is small and cozy, dim lights,

We got an order of chips which can with three different sauces that were pretty good. Chips were pretty good but nothing stand out unless you just want something to munch on. They did give us free refills of the chips though. 

In terms of the food, I really don't think you could go wrong with anything. I got the carnitas quesadillas which was HUGE. Definitely did not expect such a large portion and I wasn't able to finish it. The carnitas are spot on though. It's easy to suck at cooking pork but these were flavorful while still juicy and soft. The pineapple pico de gallo was a nice touch as well.

My friends got the tacos here which I think would have been a much more reasonable portion for dinner, so I'd go for that. The quesadillas and tacos options actually overlap quite a bit, just depends on how you want your meat served I guess.

tldr; yummy Mexican food at a decent price! nice cozy place--doesn't take reservations though
author: Jasmine X.

description: The food here is so good. Being from Los Angeles, I know good Mexican food. We shared the guacamole, queso fondito, oysters, and a variation of tacos. Their salsa verde is one of the best I've ever had. Super fresh and delicious.
author: Alexis H.

description:
The phrase "Papito Hayes" is always followed by "ooooh duck confit burrito" when my boyfriend and I talk about this place. They know how to cook and experiment with Mexican food, which is how i'm sure duck confit burritos came about. He swears by the burritos, but I love the taco options. $14 gets you 4 tacos, with is more than enough. Their carnitas and the steak are superb too. Lots of varying flavors on each taco, especially with the different salsas. Chips and salsa are always on the house, but we always get the freshly made guac, because... GUAC! Who can say no to that?! Their ceviches are also really good. We've tried all of them and have never had a bad experience. The sangrias are also a great blend of fruity flavors and red wine.

Would highly recommend for dinner!
author: Denise D.

description:
This place is great: great food, excellent service, awesome location, cool vibe. Basically, if you want good Mexican food that's not the dirt cheap Jammu stuff in the mission (which is also typically excellent don't get me wrong -- but if you're going on a date or taking out the parents) then this is the place to go

The tacos are dope, in particular the chicken one.
author: B H.

description:
This place is fabulous!!!! Had such a great meal!!! Fresh ingredients, great service, good drinks, a small but nice outdoor seating for those occasional nice SF days! 
There's a decent size menu with a lot of great options!!! The quesadilla was insane, huge and delicious!!!! 
Can't wait to go back and explore more and eat way more!!!
author: Abby R.

description:
Liked this place a lot, and we found it by Yelping the area versus going to the one I originally bookmarked. 
We were greeted and seated right away by friendly staff, and everything sounds good on their menu. 
I ordered their Carne Asada Tacos with a Margarita (can never go wrong with that pairing), and the boyfriend had Pollo Empanizado (quesadilla). I seriously liked how drink's glass rim was chili salt - not used to that. The taco meat was marinated in goodness, and I liked the thinly sliced radish in the taco with fresh avocado. Totally jealous of what my boyfriend had though. That was awesome! It was a large portion, so he decided he'd be willing to share =)
Service was also nice and efficient. Not so big on small chat, but they checked up on us during our meal, and they cleaned up after our dishes (not just waiting on us to leave).
author: Agnes S.

description: Yum! I sat at the bar and had delicious, colorful tacos, one shrimp and one baja style, paired with a fruity, extra-cold Modelo Especial on a crisp, sunny Saturday afternoon. It was kinda perfect. Will def be back.
author: Sheviche R.

description:
I am a bit late to write this review, however, I will definitely be visiting this place again so I am still on time!

I have been here twice so far and I love it. It is a bit small and they do not do reservations but you can simply walk up and place your name on the list. The wait is not too bad. The first time I ordered the Asada Enchiladas, they were served on a bed of rice and beans. The food was served hot and had plenty of flavor. Food was seasoned go perfection and the enchilada sauce had a great flavor and consistency (I hate runny sauces).

I would give 5 stars, however, I just wish they had a bigger cocktail menu. I will definitely be back and I will bring some friends next time!
author: Rudy S.

description:
Came here around 9 PM on a Saturday night.  They don't take reservations, but there was just 2 of us.. we were seated within 15 min. which was great.  

We shared the guac, a quesadilla and tacos.  Everything was delish; large portions, so I recommend sharing.  

They don't have a full bar here, but I ordered a margarita (they sub the tequila with some kind of alcohol, but I don't know exactly what), and it was tasty. 

Service was great. 

Great vibe, busy, good people watching.
author: Sarah F.

description: Seriously amazing Mole and authentic Pozole soup. Margaritas are a little bitter, but that's the right way. Very impressed.
author: G I.

description:
Came in on a Saturday night, waited 40 mins, and got seated at the spot right by the door. Being san francisco in February, it was FREEZING. They left the door open to the outside (which I partially understand as they were patrons outside -- but it was shivering cold).  

Food is pretty good.  We got the spicy fajitas (very very good) and shrimp + carnitas tacos (not bad, not great). 

Service was okay. All staff was very nice, yet it was very obvious how they were trying to turn the tables. Said I needed a few mins after ordering apps, yet less than a minute later, another waiter comes up asking for the order. 

Overall - worth a try, maybe not on a Saturday and when it's freezing. But will not be back.
author: Grover W.

description: One of my favorite spots to grab Mexican in SF! Amazing homemade chips that are served warm with their tasty salsa trio. Delicious homemade chorizo that's not too greasy like at a lot of other places. I love ceviche and they serve a great tomato-y one (ceviche Papito). Highly recommend the esquite and white sangria as well! Yummy churros too :)
author: Kara B.

description: This review is for facilities only, not food: I could not eat here because neither bathroom had soap or paper towels. I notified a hostess because this is a public health issue as these same restrooms are used by employees. She said "I told someone but there's nothing else I could do." Gross.
author: Anna B.

description:
Surely my fav Mexican in the city. Great ambience and top notch food.

My go to items here are : 
- shrimp fajitas. Usually request to get them spicy. The quantity is pretty good. 
- horchata : not too sweet and very refreshing 

Their prices are a little on the higher side but totally worth trying out if in Hayes !
author: Priyanka P.

description: The other night I enjoyed the special of the evening: a spicy shrimp soup full of the freshest shrimp, vegetables done to perfection, and the largest prawn I have ever seen. The broth was rich and flavorful, and the beans and rice that accompanied the soup were delicious. The ambiance and service were fantastic as always.
author: Aldo L.

description:
Summary for people who don't want to read this full review:  They stop serving at 10pm and then they close *the whole restaurant* down quickly.  Don't eat here if you might still be eating at 10:05pm.  Latest I would consider coming here would be 9:15pm.  Be sure to be *out* by 10pm

Here's the full review:

"Decent food; rude staff."

They close at 10pm and they mean it - if you are after 10:05 they will make it clear they want you to leave by opening up the front door, turning on all the lights, standing in front of your table and talking after changing out of work uniforms, etc.  These people really want to leave work and they let you know.  They stop serving at 10pm, turn on the lights at 10:05, change out of work clothes by 10:07pm, and then make it clear that it's time for you to leave.  Just happened to me.  

I called the waiter over at 10:09 to protest; no other restaurant I've been to does anything remotely close to this.  

Listen up Papito staff, if you know you want people to walk out the door right after 10:05, tell them in advance.  Say something like, "we are closing now and want to give you a heads up that it's not just the kitchen that closes at 10pm, the entire restaurant closes at 10pm and we close down everything. Do you still want to come in and order?"  

Be professional if you want people to come back.  It sucks that you people are so inhospitable, because your food is actually decent.  I wish you put as much care into treating your customers as you put into your food.  

I also hope an adult who manages or owns the place reads this and talks to the staff who was on duty at 10pm on 3/2/2016.
author: A A.

description: Completely enjoyed everything! Four of us were looking for dinner before a performance at DSH. Walked right in and sat down to be greeted and served. Chips and salsa, Ppapito cevechie with Prickly Pear Margaritas and cold Beers to start. I had the Mole enchiladas and they were excellent! Good service - really yummy food - cold beer... what more could you ask for.
author: Mark E.

description:
Love this place! Have come here a few times and every time I leave with smile. After having tried now their "carne Asada"(which is actually a generous, thick cut slice of meat), steak fajitas, mole poblano enchiladas, ceviche mixto, guacamole, and tres leches, I am certain that I will return and keep ordering something different each time. I want to try it all, it's that good. The food is cooked with love and precision to really capture certain flavors. I consider it authentic MEXICAN food that isn't Tex mex nor an authentic & quick tacos stand in the city. 
Their house & blood orange margaritas are so tasty. The service is great! All the staff is friendly and attentive. It is a small location so don't try and fit a party of 12 on a Friday night. 
Eating leftovers as I post this!
author: Catalina Z.

description:
The food is very average here (maybe slightly below) but the atmosphere and drinks were great.  

Not a bad place overall but depends on what you are looking for.
author: John S.

description:
Ok, I'll admit it - I don't speak Spanish. But I DO know what good Mexican food is when I have it. And Papito West in Hayes Valley certainly delivers in the "Muy Delicioso" department.

My co-workers and I walked in here on around 5pm on a Saturday and we're immediately seated in a comfy booth. I instantly befriended a Blood Orange Margarita on the cocktail menu. And we all noshed on chips, a salsa trio, and fresh guac while we leisurely perused the menu.

With so many Gourmet Mexican dishes to choose from, it was hard to decide. I finally wound up ordering the Chilaquiles (a gewy stew of tortilla chips with guajillo red sauce, English peas, white onions, bell peppers & queso fresco). I guess my diet will have to wait til next week. But it was totally worth it. The portion was huge, so I hate half of it and enjoyed the rest for lunch the next day.
My co-workers indulged in the veggie/seafood taco platter (you can get two for $9, or four for $16). They offer a variety of taco options for all kinds of taco lovers, including tempura shrimp, carnitas, skirt steak, and even fried chicken! I think I'll need to give the tacos a try my next time around (and oh yes - there will most definitely be a next time).

Service was quick and friendly. The interior is comfy, though there's nothing really memorable about the design. In fact, it felt more like a diner than it did a Mexican bistro. But what do I care? I'm not here to be Martha Stewart. I'm here to eat tasty Mexican grub. And Papito West serves plenty of it!
author: Kevin B.

description: Came here for some drinx & dessert with an old friend and thought it was fine. The wine on tap was OK and the ice cream was a bit bitter, which was due to the drop of bourbon (for the chocolate) and vodka (for the sorbet)- I don't remember that being mentioned on the menu, but highly possible that I overlooked it. Pretty small portions but a pretty good vibe and friendly staff. Probably a better spot for dinner than drinx & dessert though.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Wow..Papito really nailed it.. Guacamole a bit spicy for the kids but the pork soup was amazing. Enchiladas great though black beans maybe a bit underdone. The surprise of the night was how amazing ALL the deserts were. Homemade ice cream was was so good.
Clean and tasty!!!
author: S G.

description:
YUM YUM. What a great place with great food. It was like a delicious, gourmet taqueria. The staff was all very nice, we sat outside on a blustery night (thank goodness they have powerful outdoor heaters and covered tables). Everything we ordered was hot, fast and very large portions. The price was fair, and it was in a great area. 

I wish I could write more but some experiences can't be put into words. You'll simply have to go and experience this tasty mexican for your self. Seriously. Go. Why are you still reading this? Grab your kids, husband, wife, neighbors and GO!
author: Alec T.

description: The fried chicken super burrito was the best and they cut it for me  to share with my sister. The waiter was helpful in any questions you had. The guacamole was tasty. The spicy sauce had a very yummy taste. Didn't order any drinks but next time will order one. Very clean
author: Ron M.

description:
A little fancy for how I like my Mexican, but that's okay. Came here after biergarten on a Sunday afternoon because of their advertised oysters.

1. Asked if we wanted chips... sure! Don't you at all Mexican places? Bill came and had $3 for chips and salsa trio. That's fine, but I have this strong urge to stick to Mexican that has free chips and salsa. It just seems like a staple and safe assumption. Saw them bringing it out to many groups without calling out that it was actually a menu item. The three salsas were very small, and not that good.
2. Oysters were not clean. In probably about 1/2 of the oysters we ordered, we were spitting out pieces of shell. Don't serve oysters if you're not going to spend the time to clean them right! Ruins the experience. Accompaniments were good, however.
3. Sangria - this was the highlight. Would probably be 1 star without. Large pitcher and the red sangria tasted good.

This would really be a 2.5 star, rounded down for slow service (when empty) and steep prices.
author: Sarah B.

description:
For almost a year, I've been eating in Hayes Valley and walking right past Papito. My boyfriend and I aren't big on Mexican food, but we finally decided to give the spot a try. After one trip, we couldn't stop coming back for more, and Papito has become our favorite Mexican spot in the city!

We've only been in for brunch during which they have more breakfast items like scrambles and breakfast burritos. The breakfast burrito is truly the largest one I've seen, stuffed full with beans, rice, scrambled eggs, and meat. Although it sounds daunting, it was actually one of the lighter breakfast burritos I've tried. I also love the veggie scramble, which they somehow infuse the eggs with veggies because it comes out green and packed with delicious smoky grilled veggies and housemade cotija cheese. The highlight though, are the quesadillas. Before Papito, I had never ordered quesadillas at a restaurant. They have such a great variety of quesadillas, each with different fillings that complement each other perfectly. My favorites are the chicken (which you can ask for grilled instead of fried) and the shrimp. Meat portions are very generous and the cheese is just enough for some decadence without being too heavy. I love their mango and apple salsa that brings an extra tang, and the avocado in the shrimp quesadillas add a great creaminess. Best of all, the organic tortillas have the perfect crunch to wrap it all up. I know the Mission is the place to go for Mexican, but Papito is probably my one and only in SF!
author: Ashley T.

description: Ordered the Asada Enchilada, with a regular margarita. And tried my roommate's carne asada quesadilla with the blood orange margarita. Oh and the chips and guac  Everything was YUMMY! Sat outside under the heat lamps, enjoyed our food, and got great service. A tiny bit pricy but what isn't in the city. Would definitely come back!
author: Kelcey P.

description: Really great Mexican food at not outrageous prices. This places' tacos were as flavorful as I've ever had and the assortment of starters we got were delicious. Food-wise, this place is 5 stars, but knocking a star off for the ambiance and overall how cramped the restaurant seems.
author: Kunal M.

description: Tiny tacos-4 for 18 bucks if you order them at the same time, order 2 more. 10 bucks. Extremely expensive. I ordered the shrimp and 2 small shrimp were inside, what a joke. The service stunk too. We sat outside and she was quick to ask our order, but we needed more time. A waiter then came out 1 minute later and we were not ready, so in the beginning we felt rushed. However, after waiting some time, we had to go in and get someone. OK, not a big deal, but for some strange reason we got attitude throughout our meal. We ordered a side of aioli fries and rice, both 4 bucks each and both warm and dried up. Surely not a place I would revisit. Go a few blocks down to the Mission where you can find real Mexican food.
author: S. G.

description: Papitos has not only turned corner, they've now mastered their menu and service is spot on. Bravo, Papito! Bravo!
author: Charles H.

description: I just ordered 4 tacos take out with a side of fries. 2 tacos were Pollo Empanizado and the other two were Baja Tacos (fish). When I arrived home I could not believe my eyes. There was no fish in one taco and the other had a piece of fish the size of a quarter. The chicken tacos both had two tiny, tiny pieces of chicken the size of a dime. Are you kidding me? the total bill for this with tip was $33!!!! This place is a TOTAL RIP-OFF!. I will NEVER step foot in this joint ever again.
author: Vince F.

description:
Bugs and flies  = 0 stars in my book.

The tacos were small and mediocre, but the worst were the flies. (Picture taken 3 weeks ago.)

About 2 feet from the door of Papito's bathroom hangs not just a fly strip, but a fly *pole*. On it sticks hundreds of black bugs. While waiting for the bathroom this fly pole stood *inches* away from my face. When I realized what it was, I recoiled in horror. This is disgusting - and dangerous.

It also *reeked* of bleach or ammonia, which I can say probably isn't controlling the fly issue and definitely isn't healthy to breathe in while waiting. This is all in the hallway right next to the kitchen.

If this wasn't terrible enough I actually witnessed staff rushing around this corner carrying large silver containers of partially *open* food inches away from this pole full of flies. What?! Apparently this has been normalized. So bad, I knew I needed to write a review. Hello, health code violations?

Clean up your grossness Papito, or why would anyone want to eat there?
author: Maria A.

description: Yes, the orange margarita was devastatingly delicious, but the rest of the menu on the other hand was kinda flat. No zeal nor heat rose off of our plates like Mexican food should resemble.  I didn't like my food as much, it wasn't terrible but nothing for the tongue to really chew on...
author: Mo B.

description:
This is a nice change change from the grimy Mexican Taqueria's in the Mission; it's more of an upscale, more intimate Mexican Restaurant. I've been here a couple of times and I really enjoy the food here. 

The most recent time, I ordered the blood orange margarita which was VERY sour so beware. I enjoy sour, so I really liked this drink! We always get the corn esquites for the table. It's basically a dish of fresh grilled corn taken directly off the cob. It's very easy to eat because it's not on the cob anymore and it has a great flavor - definitely recommend this! 

For main, I've tried the veggie burrito and the veggie enchiladas. I really like the veggie burrito because it also has fresh veggies which make the burrito more unique than just beans, cheese, rice and salsa. Their take on veggie enchiladas is more like veggie tacos folded over a bed of rice and beans and drizzled with some sauce. I prefer my enchiladas more drenched in sauce so I don't like these as much as their burritos. 

Recently I also tried their flan and it was amazing! You could taste the freshness and you knew it was not made from a ready made powder. It comes served with fresh strawberries and the combination of the two is so delicious! If you have space after your meal, definitely get this!! 

Overall I really enjoy Papito; it is a little expensive compared to other Mexican restaurants but the ambiance and quality of food makes up for that!
author: Malika R.

description: We were on Hayes intending to go to another restaurant down the road, but Papito looked so good that we stopped and decided to eat there instead. It did not disappoint. We weren't starving so we split the Jicama salad (great flavors - though I'd suggest adding mixed greens to it to make it a real salad instead of just shredded vegetables) and the vegetarian quesadilla which was really delicious. Will be back to try more. Highly recommend.
author: AJ W.

description:
The service is very quick. My friend ordered the Carne Asada quesadillas and I ordered the Carnitas enchiladas, both were absolutely perfect! I was expecting a bigger portion for the enchiladas though.

I also ordered the Dulce de leche churros and trust me I will come back for those!!! Amazing!!
author: Marion K.

description:
Just had lunch here.  Really disappointing and I am curious if everything they serve is truly organic.  I emailed the owner to find out but the email bounced back as undeliverable.  The burrito I had lacked flavor and the guac had a chemical taste to it.  I was really hoping for something that wowed me especially when you use "organic" in the title of your business name, it can't just be a marketing gimmick. 
I prefer The Little Chihuahua over this place any day.  Much Better quality and flavor, along with better overall energy. after examining their website, I realized the owner was working when I went in.  Never once did he say hello or ask how the food was.  If you want to compete in the SF restaurant scene you have to step up your game and not cut corners.  Customers notice.  I won't be back.
author: T L.

description:
Yummy... ordered the carne asada tacos and I'm a fan forever....will definity go back
to truth other menu items.  Churros were a little over cooked and could have used
some ice cream.
author: Missy M.

description: the food tasted my fresh. waiter was friendly. service was fast. definitely recommend the super burrito, and don't hold back. it will put up a fight
author: Mohamad N.

description: Hot damn. I've never had ceviche this good, and I spent a summer in Lima. Incredibly fresh ingredients, exacting attention to detail, and the perfect blend between richness, sweetness, and spice. I cannot recommend the ceviche highly enough, and I early look forward to returning soon.
author: Michael A.

description: So many other good Mexican restaurants around. Skip this one. Mediocre Mexican food trying to pass as "hip" bc they're on Hayes Street. To their credit their carnitas tacos are ok. But I would suggest they don't drown all their tacos in so much pico. Who likes soggy tortillas? And their papa w/chorizo wouldn't be my first choice. Staff is passive aggressive...
author: Briana G.

description: Tried this place for dinner on a Friday night. Can you believe they charge for chips and salsa? Also, the chips tasted like store bought Tostitos and the salsa's weren't any better. The service was a little lacking as well. Why the 3 stars? My boyfriend ordered the enchiladas and those were pretty good. I wouldn't come here again, or wait for a table. Overrated.
author: Dani P.

description:
Ummm loved it!

It's not your hole in the wall burrito joint that serves up some dirty delicious food frequented by homeless and hipsters alike --- it's a much cleaner, modern, classy yet casual mexican joint that serves all organic food that they pretty much make everything at the place. 

The service is very friendly, the food was clean and delicious, and the place is just really nice and modern -- will definitely be back!
author: Nolan M.

description:
This place is in walking distance to where I live,
I ate dinner few times so far and every time I was treated nicely by the staff.
The food quality is also good for the price 
Some times you have to wait in line to get a table but since I eat alone I normally get a table fast outside or an spot at the bar
author: Arash R.

description:
If you love Mexican flavors, but can't take the heat, this is the perfect kitchen for you. There's a solid bit of flavor, but zer0 spice. 

I personally need my Mexican food to have a bit of a kick, so for that, I give it 3 stars. But the space is cute (read: nice but small) and the service was good. 

We ordered the guacamole, veggie quesadillas and veggie enchiladas. 
- Guacamole was good, but heavy on the lime juice. And not worth $9
- Veggie quesadillas were the highlight for me. unfortunately, there's no salsa on the side, only a very light zag of the Oaxaca sauce. Give me a side of that stuff to dip in and I might up the review to a 4. 
- Enchiladas... these were more like non-fried taquitos. There isn't enough cheese to hold anything together, so the filling falls right out of the enchilada. Order these if you like eating a small fajita. 

I won't be rushing to get back, but won't object if someone insists on going here.
author: Dimple B.

description: Pricey for Mexican, but fantastic. The 4 taco plate was wonderful as were the beans and rice. The shrimp taco was really nice but the one I will come back for is the simple battered fish taco. It was phenomenal. -1 because a Mexican place should NEVER charge for chips. But the atmosphere was nice, as is the rest of Hayes.
author: Onik R.

description:
Highlights
- Love the fact that they opened this 2nd location aside from their original in the Portero Hill district. 
- Spacious, plenty of seating, no wait for weekend lunch, and service was great. 
- Vegetariano Quesadilla: their fried chicken or shrimp option still surpasses this one, but if you are not feeling meat this is a great option. Loaded with sautéed vegetables, came in a spinach tortilla, drizzled with sour cream, and side salsa provided. 

Improvements
- This location did not give free chips and salsa trio like their other location. $3 if you would like to add this to your meal. 
- Fried Chicken Eggs Benedict: Interesting brunch menu item that they offered, but the chicken was overly chewy from being over fried and egg was overcooked and not runny. 

Tips: 
- Parking isn't the best here, search for a local neighborhood spot on the weekend if possible. 
- This location has more menu items and seating if you plan to come with a larger party, but if you don't mind a smaller space their original location is still the best in my book.
author: Tracy T.

description:
We received excellent service. The staff was incredibly nice and attentive. My husband and I even had a small conversation about it during our menu.

We first noticed this place on our morning walks, they are always cleaning early in the AM with fun music blasting. Our first visit, this evening, was long over due and well worth it. 

My husband enjoyed his shrimp fajitas, as did I since I stole more than a few bits. The chips and salad are delicious at $3. 

They were also kind enough to give our dogs a fresh bowl of water when we first sat down.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Don't have much to say except that I would rate this as one of my top Mexican restaurants in the city.  A lot of the folks I go out with are vegetarian and this place has great vegetarian options as well. Not just one or two but quite a few : roasted corn, queso fundido, enchiladas, tacos etc.
The only tricky part is that they do not take reservations so if you are a big group you might have to wait for a bit before you get a table, but trust me, its worth the wait.
author: Varun A.

description: Very friendly environment. The food and service was great and fast! Not too heavy, but felt full.
author: Colgan P.

description: I came to Papito Hayes with a few friends for brunch on Saturday morning since the other good brunch places nearby were quite packed and required waiting in line.  However, we were pleased where we discovered that Papito Hayes didn't have any line at all.  I had the pollo frito poached eggs and I must say that I loved the Mexican adaptation of the traditional eggs benedict.  The poached eggs were perfectly cooked (had the right runny consistency), the fried chicken was crispy, and the hollandaise sauce was smooth.  I also got fruit as a side since I was trying to adhere to my 2016 new years resolution to eat healthier.  The fruit was plentiful, included a diverse assortment of fruit types, and tasted fresh.  Our waitress was also very friendly (she seemed to love my hooded sweater, which she commented looked like it was from Helmut Lang).  Overall, a wonderful foodie experience.
author: Kenneth S.

description:
absolutely love this place!  the food was delicious and the portions are HUGE!  we had the charred jalapeno margartia & the special prickly pear margartia.  both were really good and the smoky chili salt added a great punch.  we also had the steak fajitas- the portion was HUGE!  it was delicious with the beef cooked perfectly, the vegetables and accompaniments were plentiful and lovely.  we also had the chicken quesadilla with fries which was very tasty.  

the service is really good; everyone is super attentive and you can tell they work as a good team.  the place is super tiny so get there early.  can't wait to go back!
author: Samantha B.

description:
I really did not care for this place!

We started with the guacamole, which was good. The chips were okay. For a restaurant of this caliber, I was expecting them to be thin, crisp, and homemade. They tasted like they were from a bag.

We tried 5 different tacos, one of which was good (shrimp).
- The duck taco was mediocre. 
- Our server recommended the fried chicken taco, which I thought sounded interesting and different. It was not good. The chicken was over-fried, to the point where the batter was hard, and the chicken itself was dry. The sauce that comes with this is also very very spicy. 
- I can handle the spiciness of a chorizo taco. I eat them at Tacolicious all the time, and I also love chorizo and eggs for breakfast. This chorizo taco was so spicy (no indicator on the menu either) that I wasn't able to eat it. They were kind enough to let me change it out for another taco.
- When I asked which tacos were not spicy, they said there was only one: the fish taco. So I got that, but it was so over-fried that the batter was a dark brown and was so hard that it was not edible. I peeled the batter off in chunks to try and eat the fish inside. 

We ended with churros for dessert, which were also over-friend. It seems this place does not know how to fry foods properly.

Overall a huge disappointment. I will not be back again.
author: Jaching H.

description:
Pros: 
-Blood Orange Margarita was delish
-Albondigas appetizer is huge
-I liked the atmosphere and the look of the place

Cons:
-Took a while to get the check 
-Albondigas dish was on the salty side 

I'd come back ^-^
author: Rose G.

description:
I ate here with some friends who were Air BnB'ing nearby.  I didn't love it.  Here's why:

Friends arrived first, put name down, were quoted 20 min, not bad for a Friday night.  A waiter/host/bartender kindly offered to get us started with drinks while we waited.  I ordered a michelada, it was super watery and not all that pleasant, I am a great lover of micheladas, so perhaps I'm picky.  It took quite a bit longer than 20 minutes for us to be seated, but c'est la vie, the booth we were waiting for had campers in it.

We started out with guac and a dozen oysters (hey, it's an "oysteria" after all).  We got the kumamotos (my fave).  The guacamole was truly delicious, no complaints there whatsoever.  The kumamotos arrived and I went to eat my first one.  I squeezed some lime on there and knocked him back as you do, when my mouth was filled with an abhorrent flavor that I could only describe as "barnyard."  Despite chugging some water and eating a chip or two, the off-taste lingered in my mouth for a looong time.  I immediately realized that I'd just eaten a spoiled oyster.  Needless to say, my appetite was a bit... reduced after that.  My dining companions said their oysters didn't taste spoiled, but they definitely didn't taste fresh.  We all noted that the oysters had no brine left in them and in fact were dry, and we surmised that they had perhaps been shucked and left to sit, which is not how you're supposed to treat oysters.  They go bad FAST after shucking, so this is probably why mine was so nasty.  I alerted our waiter that I'd had a spoiled oyster.  She asked me if I wanted another one.  Hmmm... not the response I was expecting.  I simply said, no I didn't want another.  I was alerting her not to get one free oyster, but to bring to her attention a potential food safety concern, as spoiled shellfish can cause food-poisoning.  She didn't seem to comprehend that, as she expressed no concern.

I had a bite or two of the enchiladas I'd already ordered, but as I said, I didn't have much of an appetite.  I was contemplating the likelihood that I'd be stricken with food-borne illness and how soon it might hit, and this is not particularly conducive to enjoying one's meal.  My friends said that their enchiladas were a bit dry and under-seasoned.

Thankfully, I made it through the night without any nausea-induced interruptions, but I was worried.

Our check was credited $3.60, presumably for one oyster, plus tax.  This is a weird thing to do.

I truly have concerns about how they are handling oysters here.  If I were to come back, which I likely will not, I would not feel comfortable eating oysters here again.

Long story short, they bill themselves as an "oysteria" and yet at least one person here does not seem to know much about oysters.
author: Rachel S.

description: I tried this place for the first time tonight and was pleasantly surprised! It's an adorable little restaurant. We were seated immediately at the bar and had prompt service from the staff. We ordered the chips and salsa, mole con pollo enchiladas, and 4 tacos(fried chicken, carnitas, carne asada, and cod). The salsa verde was really good, the salsa rojo was too tomatoey for my taste, and the mango salsa tasted great but was very thin with no pieces on actual mango in it. The chicken enchiladas were wonderful! Just the right amount of spice. All of the tacos were great but the cod and fried chicken were my favorite. This place has met the balance between a fancy restaurant and a cute little taqueria. I'd love to come back and try some more menu items!
author: Amy S.

description: Saturdays are busy... But if you can handle the wait it is well worth it. I ordered 4 tacos; 2 asada and 2 carnitas. They were delicious. Freshly made with extra sauce, just like I like it... The servers were great. There were 14 of us and they took care of us all very well.
author: Terrence M.

description: What a little gem of a spot in San Francisco! The best fresh blood orange margaritas we've ever had. Bartender is phenomenal! Meals and bites are expertly prepared, so fresh and flavorful. Pork fajitas and shrimp dish were fabulous, service the best! Stop here!
author: Jackie P.

description: My daughter and I went for quick bite before the concert in SF. We love it. There are plenty of vegetarian options for my daughter, which is nice. I had ceviche and she had shrimp taco. Both are excellent, good flavor. Good music in background. Oh, we had guacamole, too. That was good. I saw some people commented that this is for Anglo American yuppies (which we are not), I am happy to take it. :)
author: Kazuko A.

description:
I have taken a long break from Yelp.. Why, you ask? Because I moved to San Francisco and realized that every restaurant in this city has tons of reviews. How do you people sort through the bullS$$$ to find useful reviews? I took a break, because I thought the literature (yes I consider my yelp reviews literature) would not be appreciated nor considered in making informed decisions. Why am I writing a review now you ask? because I am drunk on a plane, heading home searching for a good restaurant in the either SF or the east bay and realized that my literature might actually have value in the Pacific Ocean of yelp reviews we call the Bay Area. At this point you have probably stopped reading this useless banter , if you haven't, I'm impressed the review will start right about now...

Guys the food is delicious, the shrimp fajitas (extra spicy) is not only instagram worthy but it excites the far reaches of your taste buds. do not waste time with the tres leche dessert (It aint tres leches, more like uno leche!) 

I am still trying to understand the restaurant vibe in SF. Are you supposed to spend money on Mexican food in this city? this is a bit $$ (notice the 2 $$ signs) when there are awesome taquerias ($) every where. Either way it was really good and not too expensive.
author: Gautam T.

description:
DISCLAIMER: I'm a Taqueria BETTER THAN Mexican Restaurant type of guy. Papito did not disappoint however--though my Mexican amigo visiting from out of town was a bit bummed out by his Carne Asada Enchiladas. Understandable. An Enchilada should not be overcomplicated with too many ingredients yet little flavor. My meal, on the other hand, got the job done fairly well. The GF and I shared an Albondigas app & Smothered Veggie Burrito (BOTH sauces). The Albondigas app was really just a Roasted Brussel Sprouts app that just so happened to also have 2 meatballs--dem sprouts was delish tho! Just wish I knew what I was getting into beforehand...now I do. And now you do, Dear Reader. The Veggie Burrito was the size of a GROWN MAN's work boot and absolutely filled to the brim and covered in sauces, one half Red Sauce & the other Green Sauce. The better sauce? Psshh, that's like asking a parent who their favorite kid is. I just can't answer that. Not publicly at least. 

A bit pricey IMO but overall a pretty delicious meal. Next time I'm in the city I may have to seek out a Greasy Burrito in the Mission tho.
author: Jon S.

description: This is my favorite Mexican food in the city! The food is awesome and the price is fair! All the attendants are very kind! Loved this place!!!
author: Melvin R.

description:
Mix of mediocre and good food in a hipper environment than your standard taqueria. Love the margaritas and enjoy sitting outside under the heaters (it's actually quieter and much more spacious than the tables outside Absinthe). 

I recommend the guac and chicken fajitas. Avoid the salads (basically an avocado atop lettuce of questionable freshness) and the fish tacos (unseasoned and all around meh).
author: Alyssa Y.

description:
Great tacos. Really good. The fried chicken taco was one of a kind. Good beers and chip which come with three types of salsa too. Very filling. I could not eat any more which was too and as their desserts seem awesome too.

However; an hour after eating there I came down with explosive diarrhoea... So something of the above must have been full of very, very bad bacteria. I really hate getting sick from eating out, so will not be coming back. And which explains the two stars. Otherwise it wound probably have been four stars (as service was a bit slow, while the food at least tasted five star). But who wants to spend an hour on the toilet after going out to eat?
author: A D.

description:
Very good food with attentive and courteous staff!
The only complaint I have is the lack of air conditioning and the day we went happened to be very hot.

The good food and service as well as good company made up for that though. Would like to go back and try dishes other than the quesadilla... it was good and super thick and cheesy, just the way I like!
author: Sera P.

description: Nothing is that great. I've had their ceviches, enchiladas, chips and guacamole, fajitas, tacos and burritos. Burritos would be my only recommendation. Only end up at the restaurant when others on Hayes have too long a wait.
author: Laura D.

description: Quaint mexican spot in the middle of Hayes Valley that definitely exceeded my expectations! It was a busy Saturday evening and wait was fairly long, so we decided to settle for the patio seating outside despite the cold. The heat lamps kept us warm so it was still a great experience. The food was absolutely delicious! The carnitas enchilada is one of their most popular entrees and it was devour-able. The pork was soft and it fell apart in my mouth with every bite. The portions were large and I couldn't even finish it despite how much i wanted to. The chicken quesadillas were also good with a nice healthy portion of guacamole but they were quite standard. I would definitely recommend the enchilada over everything else. We came here to celebrate my friend's birthday so they brought out a candle and sang Happy Birthday while we got our chocolate mousse dessert. I'm definitely looking forward to returning soon!
author: Lisa H.

description: YAAAAAAAAAS! This place is amazing! I had the shrimp quesadilla, and it was the best! The ambience and vibe is great as well. I have nothing negative to say about my experience. Good Job Papito Hayes!
author: Jared O.

description:
They add a lot of pumpkin seeds on everything (previously I tried the chilequellas which I would have to say I've definitely had better - and of course had pumpkin seeds on top). I would be quite happy without them --- and it would save them time and money.

The enchiladas were okay. Not bursting with flavor though, and only a drizzle of sauce. I would have been happier with 2 less enchiladas and a side of rice instead. Large serving though for $15. Still a bit pricey though.

Salsa and chips are great. A red salsa, green salsa and a mango pure salsa that was delicious. Chips are light but not to thin.


They do have several options for vegetarians which is nice but a bit expected with a Mexican restaurant.

No alcohol and sodas come in either cans or bottles.
author: Zoe D.

description:
